title: Neighbours pull family from burning house in Hamilton
text:
Neighbours pull family from burning house in Hamilton LIBBY WILSON Last updated 12:53, February 26 2017 MARK TAYLOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
A woman was injured and the family's belongings were destroyed when a fire started in their Hamilton home. 
A smoky blaze that wrecked a Hamilton home has injured one person and destroyed a family's belongings. 
It's understood residents in Plateau Drive, Fitzroy, pulled a woman and children out of the house moments before it was engulfed by flames. 
Five fire crews sped to the blaze about 6.45pm on Saturday and ambulance officers were called to treat a woman for burns. MARK TAYLOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Five fire engines battled the smoke and flames in Plateau Drive, Fitzroy, on Saturday night. 
By Sunday morning, shocked residents were gathering in the street and planning how to help those who live in the house. 
READ MORE: 
The family lost everything and are not thought to have insurance. MARK TAYLOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
The garage was also gutted in the blaze. 
But there was some good news - firefighters who arrived to check the scene on Sunday pulled out an undamaged skateboard and handed it to the kids on the street. 
Once the blaze started on Saturday evening, neighbours piled out into the street and there were multiple calls to 111. 
A mother and at least two children - including a baby - have rented the house for about four years and they are well thought of in the street. 
The mother is thought to have been asleep at the time the fire took hold. 
A woman who did not wish to be named ran for a fire extinguisher, but by the time she got back, the fire was too strong for it to have any effect. 
"I looked over and it was just gone," she said. 
"It was all panic stations." 
Tina Harris, who is visiting family in the street, agreed. 
"Everything just happened so fast," she said. 
"We just saw it go up in smoke." 
Robert Wilson was just getting back into Hamilton when he heard sirens heading in the direction of Plateau Drive, where his son lives. 
"When we saw the smoke, we started to panic," he said. 
"We really started to panic when we came around the corner and saw the fire brigade." 
Once he realised it wasn't his son's house, he started wondering if anyone had been hurt. 
And now he wants to make sure his son gets a smoke alarm put in. 
Neighbours said there had been a steady flow of rubberneckersâ€‹ on Sunday 
Plateau Drive residents are considering putting out a donation box or setting up a Givealittle page. 
Police attended the fire, but were unable to provide many details. 
On Sunday morning, the injured woman was stable and being cared for in a ward, a Waikato District Health Board spokeswoman said. - Stuff
